Posts.Content: I found radio more tiring than chemo (having to queue for 3/4 hour each time at the BRI to get a parking space didn't help plus the hot flushes following chemo were at a level of many each hour at that time).  My skin got a bit pink during the boost phase and again in the last couple of days but the aqueous cream stopped it getting any worse (slapped it on four times a day).  What they don't tell you until you near the end is that you go on 'cooking' for at least 10 days and it's best to stick with the non-underwired bras for a further month as the skin will still be sensitive.  I'm two months on now and pretty much back to normal.
Posts.Title: radio therapy

Posts.Content: I've not started tamoxifen yet  and am 12 days after the last dose of FEC.  I also had the cold cap and my hair's thinned quite a bit but I've been getting some regrowth since around the third FEC.  I was originally advised to use baby shampoo but ended up with a really spotty scalp and was told to go back to my usual organic stuff which seems to be doing ok.  The new hair's definitely curly and white - shows up nicely in the remains of my natural caramel brown straight locks!  I can't use head and shoulders as it makes me itch but am using a Jason shampoo that's supposed to be good for hair vitality - the sooner it thickens up the better but I know I'm still going to shed a bit more before things improve (mine usually sheds a bit around 3 1/2 weeks after chemo). Chrissi
Posts.Title: Reaction to tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Probably a bit late to be of use but my consultant's recommended starflower oil to go with tamoxifen (I'm hormone positive).  I've got a chillow but find that it only works for an hour or two before the cold effect wears off.  I think the starflower's starting to work - I've been taking it for about 10 days now.
Posts.Title: Hot flushes!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi there I have been on Arimidex since January this year.  I have put on a stone+ in weight since starting this hormone therapy. I am not a big eater and what I do eat is healthy.  Lots of fruit, veggies, protein, salads etc.  I don't eat between meals and rarely have cakes,biscuits chocolate sweets etc.  I drink peppermint tea, diet coke sometimes and wine/G&T, perhaps once a week. I walk, go to red hot yoga 2/3 times a week too but the weight just keeps coming. I hate how my body has changed, my tummy is especially bad but it's all over, my legs, bottom and even on my back and from what I can find out it is going to get even worse. Has anyone experienced the same? What or is there anything more you can do to help yourself? Chrissi P x
Posts.Title: Arimadex

Posts.Content: Hello Kate    Many thanks for your reply. I have taken time to read various posts regarding the increase in weight that some ladies face once they are on the hormone therapy. For some ladies there is no weight gain, I wish I was one of them but hey that's not to be. I am not a big eater and quite often don't have an appetite at all. I went onto the Slimming World diet for a time but found that the volume of food was too much for me. However I do still cook with little or no oils or fats which is good. I do take regular exercise too, obviously it's not enough.  Since joining the McMillan site I realise that my issue is so small in comparison to many of the ladies out there who are in constant pain, have to cope with a multitude of drugs, facing chemo, radiotherapy etc etc. It makes me feel so guilty, ungrateful, ungracious, unworthy and even vane. I hope I'm none of those things. It's just when you have always been able to keep a fairly trim figure and suddenly it goes to pot it makes me feel angry I suppose. I hate myself physically but more so emotionally.  I hope you are able to keep well as you continue on your journey too.    Bye for now.    Best wishes.    Chrissi P
Posts.Title: Arimadex

Posts.Content: Just found this thread...  I'm (hopefully) having my third FEC on Thursday.  It's now day 20 of the second cycle and I've still got most of my hair thanks to the cold cap.  The pain from the cold only lasts a couple of minutes with each cap replacement (for me) and I've not ended up getting wet from it defrosting (in fact there's no water - it's just a neoprene icepack really so no moisture dripping like some have experienced).  My nurses have said it really does work and is worth perservering with.  Someone at the weekend asked when I was starting treatment and would I lose my hair so it must be working.  My hair started shedding on day 15 of the first treatment and that went on for about 5 or 6 days but this cycle if there are a dozen hairs in my comb in the morning it's a lot.  Just make sure the cap touches your scalp all over - I don't think mine did first time around. I'd say go for it - I had to ask to have the cap as it's not always offered automatically.  The hospital I'm being treated at are very good with their advice and I've met other people who've used the cap and are towards the end of their treatment and had very little hair loss.  I guess it doesn't work for everyone but is worth trying.  For me it means I've not had to tell my dad I'm having treatment as I still look 'normal' - he'd worry himself silly as he's of the opinion that cancer means an early grave and wouldn't believe that my consultant says the cancer's gone and this is preventative treatment to stop anything that's lurking turning nasty in the future. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Hair loss/cold cap and FEC-T

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm having my 6th and final FEC tomorrow if my bloods are ok this afternoon.  I've had the cold cap and apart from the feeling of sticking your head in a bucket of ice for the first 3 minutes I have to say it's not as bad as I'd been told to expect.  My hair thinned about day 24 after the first FEC - felt like it was coming out in handfuls but probably not as bad as it seemed - but I've still got more than enough hair to go out without a hat and for my dad not to have realised there's anything wrong (haven't told him I've been ill because he'd panic and although I see him most weeks the most he's noticed is that I've put on weight).  If you get the chance to try the cap go for it - you can always change your mind but it's certainly worth sticking it out for at least 2 doses just so you can see if it works for you.  (I've also still got eyebrows and most of my upper eyelashes - the lower ones go each time - and the odd hair on my legs and arms so you don't necessarily lose all body hair with FEC). As for veins etc.  No one suggested anything other than finding a vein each time for me and I've been fine.  No problems so far.
Posts.Title: Should I have a portocath?

Posts.Content: Hi Katie, everywhere I go I seem to come across more and more people who've been through this.  Where I work there are 10 women, I'm number 2 to get this, where I worked before there were 12 women, again 2 of us have had this.  My tai chi class has 7 women - yes, two of us have been here (my husband's dentist is just finishing his chemo for it too - seems if you don't know someone who's been through this you're in the minority!).  Why do they only do routine scans after 50?  I'm 45 and my lump was only detected because I felt something which turned out to be nothing and I got a scan which showed my lump (consultant couldn't feel the lump at all so I'm feeling mega lucky I had a reason to visit my GP and she got me in to see the consultant immediately otherwise I'd still be in ignorance!).  What I'd felt had vanished a week later so probably was just hormonal changes or bruising - I feel so incredibly lucky that I had a reason to see my GP at that time as it meant my lump was only about 1.5cm and it was picked up before lymph nodes etc were affected.  Anyway, I'm feeling much better today.  The heartburn and indigestion's a lot easier (although still not quite right I'm feeling a bit bloated and sore rather than wanting to curl up in a corner and hide from the pain).  I skived off walking the dogs with my husband at 6am today but am feeling alive again - it's a beautiful day, shame I'm at work!   Just need to get moving a bit more now so I can build up a bit more energy before the next treatment.  It certainly helps knowing we're all going through this but also at the same time it's heartbreaking that we are here.  Chrissi xx
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Andrea, I know what you mean.  At no point  have I felt ill.  I've felt angry, very frustrated and bloody mindedly determined to get on with this and get it over and done with (and the day before the op and the morning of chemo pretty scared - never had general anaesthetic or any but the most basic hospital treatment before) but never actually ill (not even immediately after the op - but as my op only took half an hour and I was home 2 hours later I guess it didn't hit my body that bad).  Last time I saw the surgeon to get the final results from the lump he said that he was satisfied he'd removed all the cancer and that the treatment from now on was 'belt and braces' to keep me healthy in the future.  Him putting it that way certainly helped put it in perspective.  The oncologist also described the chemo and radiation as a mopping up job just incase the odd cell was dropped in the op or I've got other cells elsewhere that are contemplating misbehaving.  For me chemo was described as optional but having it would give me a better chance of not getting any further problems than your average person on the street.  I guess that's kind of right - noone knows if there's something lurking inside them waiting to cause problems but at least those of us who are having post op chemo know we're getting in first and dealing with potential future problems now in the best way known to medical science. A friend who went through all this a few years ago (before we met) describes herself as a cancer survivor in a very special club where she gets private quality medical care on the NHS for the rest of her life (she refused to ever be a cancer patient or a cancer sufferer) and I'm hoping I can deal with it as well as she has. Chrissi xxx
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: 'Morning all, it's day 11 after first chemo for me and I've decided to take notice of the nurses and keep away from people for a couple of days so am working from home at least until Wednesday (I'll be climbing the walls by then!).  I'm still feeling pretty good although a bit tired today - probably did too much over the weekend and got woken up a few times last night (my dogs need slippers to muffle their claws on the wooden floor boards - why do they feel the need to creep around at 2am then again at 4am when I'm really tired???). Hat, my GP also suggested that forums tend to be frequented mainly by those who have problems and that most people sail through the treatment with no problems.  Her view was that forums are useful for support because you're all going through the same thing so long as you keep in mind that the vast majority of people don't use them and don't have any problems. Josie,  I'm just having 6 rounds of FEC followed by radiation and tamoxifen (hopefully that means I'll at least keep my nails).  My mouth felt like I'd just recovered from a bad cold last week - bit furry and taste not quite right, this morning I've got a slightly metallic taste but the furriness has improved a lot.  All my hair's still in place at the moment.  Hopefully the cold cap will prevent me losing much but at least the weather's warming up.  I got my wig last Thursday - my hair's fairly fine and the wig has more hair than I've ever had.  It looks ok but 'too perfectly styled' for me so hopefully I'm not going to need it (wonder if there's a good market on ebay for second hand wigs when this is all over???). My scars are only a month old and are still a bit tender and lumpy - more so when I'm tired or when I've done more than I should (I was working in the garden for a few hours yesterday and certainly know about it this morning - well, since the operation a month ago I suppose I've taken things easier than usual and it's hit my fitness levels).  I've started massaging lightly with bio oil and it does seem to help.  My arm was very sore when the nerves started healing but is much better now.  Luckily I only needed a small lump and a couple of lymph nodes removed and the lump was in from my breast bone so there was very little damage to muscles and I had full movement in my arm all the way through.  Hope we're all going to have a good week.  For me it's important to know that people are doing ok as well as helping to support those that are feeling under the weather. Good luck, another week nearer the end of treatment! Chrissi xxx
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Noj, actually I joined this site quite a few years ago for info when my mum had terminal cancer and have used it since for info when my father-in-law was dying.  I joined for information primarily and secondarily to be able to chat about what's going on with people who are in the same place (my husband is great but it's very hard for him to see me 'ill' and not be able to do anything to make things better and it's not fair for me to put all my problems to him). I think the medical profession have a good point - the way my GP put it, explaining that most people are doing ok and to remember that those that have problems are a very unfortunate minority, is the right way to describe the forums.  Yes, the forums are very useful, but we have to remember that just because one person is experiencing a certain side-effect it doesn't mean we all will and not to expect to experience that problem - that's the point my GP was making.  She wanted to tell me to remain positive and expect to sail through the treatment in the hope that it would help me to treat problems as minor set-backs and keep a positive attitude towards my treatment (which in turn would help me to deal with any problems that hit me). I have to admit the first time I looked at the breast cancer forum I thought 'oh my god!  How am I going to cope with all those problems people are describing' That was the day before my first chemo session and I scared myself silly by reading how ill some people had felt - my main worry was that people have been off work for months during treatment - if I miss more than a month of work in the year I'm going to be on statutory sick pay and my savings will be disappearing rapidly.  At that point I had almost decided not to come back here but I went to my GPs surgery the day after chemo for my swine flu injection and the nurse said to try the forums again and to post when I felt good as well as when I felt bad because there would be plenty of others who wanted to know that it's not all bad and that you can feel good. So, today I feel good!  I'm bored with being at home avoiding contact with people because of where I am in my chemo cycle, but compared with what I expected for my first cycle I'm doing fine.    Chrissi
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hat, interested to see you couldn't manage a shandy.  I've felt no desire for alchohol at all since my first chemo.  I did have a glass of white wine with dinner on Saturday - we had mother-in-law, brother-in-law etc over and that usually gets me drinking more than usual (it's either that or say something I might regret!) - and only managed a few sips and swapped to shloer without anyone noticing (mother-in-law has no idea that I've had cancer let alone going through chemo - hopefully we'll keep it that way, it took her 4 months to spot I'd had 8 inches chopped off my hair and we see her usually twice a week so she's not going to notice if I wear hats and headscarfs a bit more than usual and will probably think my wig looks better than my hair normally does anyway).  The wine tasted fine, I just didn't want it and woke at about 2am with a splitting headache.  I've decided not to try red wine again until my chemo finishes as a friend said it tasted really wrong for her and put her off her favourite drink for life. Chrissi
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm hoping I'll be lucky and my veins will stand up to the chemo and I won't need a line put in - for once I'll be glad that I've got the sort of veins that stand out even on the coldest of days (my mum had veins that turned shy and hid at the mere thought of a needle which was a real problem). I'm now on day 7 after chemo and my op was exactly a month ago today so it sounds as though my treatment's been progressed quite a bit faster than some of you (I was told I'd recovered well from the op but as it apparently only took half an hour to do it was very minor - counting my blessings!).  This morning I walked the dogs with my husband at 6am - my first morning out since chemo.  I'd expected to feel exhausted after half a mile but managed our usual route of a a couple of miles in half an hour.  I'm actually feeling fairly normal - got some 'dry' patches in my mouth and still feel as though I've had one too many late nights but the indigestion's virtually gone now.  My hair's still holding in but my scalp feels a bit prickly (like I can feel the hair growing) so not sure if the cold cap's worked or not at the moment.  Strangely my eye lashes seem to have grown over the last week and look thicker than usual (usually very straggly) so I'm wondering if they've put on a last ditch burst of energy before they depart (body hair's still growing - my husband says he's looking forward to me not pinching his razor though). I was told that chemo would probably stop my periods, at least temporarily.  For the first time in many years (I've been peri-menopausal since before I hit 40, now 45) my period's turned up precisely one month after the last one and with no PMT (over the last few years I've gone months with nothing apart from the PMT bit).   The advantage of getting to this stage earlier than most is that the mammogram clearly showed my lump.  The human body is definitely bizarre in the way it reacts to outside influences. I spoke to oncology yesterday and they're fairly confident they'll stop the heartburn and indigestion next time and also that if I'm sensible with eating and light exercise I should be able to avoid weight gain so am feeling more confident about the next few months.  Just waiting to hear back about a wig now.  I went to be measured last week and of course they had nothing in stock that would suit me so said they'd get a couple of possible styles in this week - the idea of having hair that doesn't develop a mind of it's own and only looks good on the day I've visited the hairdresser is actually quite appealing! I'm working in the office today but think I might work from home the rest of the week just to avoid bugs etc as much as possible until my system starts to recover a bit. Hope everyone's doing ok today, Luv, Chrissi xxx
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: I think maybe I've been lucky with the breast cancer unit at my local hospital - they've got an excellent reputation for breast cancer care.  I was assigned a Macmillan breast care nurse before I got confirmation of diagnosis and every step of the way I've been kept informed.  On the day of the op she was in the day care ward keeping an eye on all her charges before and after the operations and since has emailed me regularly to check on my progress (she knows I'm working and sat in front of the pc all day).  The nurse dealing with my chemo went through a massive list of side effects, do's and don'ts before plumbing me in - in fact it took her longer to go through all the information than it did to have the treatment (a good hour and a half at least) and I was encouraged to phone the ward if I  have any questions whatsoever.  For me the physical scars are not a problem.  I know people with far worse scars than I've got and they are able to deal with them (I only found out that one friend had had a mastectomy when we were all sunbathing on holiday about 15 years ago and she was the first on the beach to go topless and I've felt that if she could be that confident with her body then I must be able to deal with a couple of relatively small scars and a slight mismatch in size).   It also helps that my husband isn't at all bothered about the scarring.  The thing that I find difficult is that I'm not as strong as I was 5 weeks ago and get tired more easily - that really, really frustrates me.  I hate asking for help and know that if I get more tired with each treatment I'm going to be a nightmare to live with.  At the moment having to be sensible and avoid the general public because I'm at my lowest point immune system-wise is really, really frustrating.  I'm wondering what others do at this point after their treatment?  Do you take the opportunity to put your feet up and relax or do you think 'what the heck' and carry on as normal? Chrissi
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Josie, luckily I love ginger so yes, that does help.  I find the indigestion goes when I eat but reappears a bit later although it's taking me longer to eat meals than usual at the moment.  I'm hoping that with eating slower I'm going to avoid weight gain as I've put on 1/2 stone since diagnosis already (and my waistbands won't cope with much more).   Keeping in touch will be great - will be good to be in touch with someone who's moving at the same rate as me.  My next treatment's on 1st April (someone's got a sense of humour out there) so I'll have Easter to recover.  I've now been at work over 2 hours and am actually feeling a bit more awake than I did when I got here.  I'm hoping to work through this as much as I can (I can work from home if necessary but it's better being in the office with people) - I only get one month's full pay for sick leave and so far haven't needed to use any of it but with radiation to follow on from the chemo I know I'll need some time off over the summer... Love, Chrissi
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my first FEC last thursday with cold cap (following lumpectomy and sentinal lymph node removal about 3 1/2 weeks ago - lymph nodes were fine and plenty of healthy tissue around the lump).  No sickness (felt fine Thursday and Friday) but have had horrible indigestion since but is getting better since I finished the two days of steroids on Saturday.   I spoke to the local oncology ward on Saturday but they didn't seem that interested in me feeling grotty and just suggested gaviscon as they believed the steroids didn't agree with me.  Had plenty of energy over the weekend but I'm feeling pretty tired today and blurred but am at work and vertical.  My skin's gone a bit dry - hands look about 20 years older than last week but hopefully plenty of handcream will keep that under control.  I'm keeping telling myself that it's 1 down, 5 treatments to go...  Has anyone else suffered from indigestion?  Any suggestions for how to get it under control please? Many thanks, Chrissi
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Connor, I was diagnosed early feb (felt a lump, lump didn't show as a problem on scans but another one - 1.5cm - showed up that wasn't felt by me or the consultant so am considering myself incredibly lucky), operation on the 17th and first chemo 11th March.  So far I've missed just one day of work (the day of the op although if I'd known I'd have been sitting waiting until 4pm I'd have taken something to do in with me!).  I'm having 6 rounds of FEC (followed by radiation and tamoxifen) and was expecting last Thursday to be horrible.  For me it was ok.  The hospital's fairly small but has an excellent reputation as a breast clinic and the day ward where the chemo's done is really bright and friendly (arm chairs, not beds and radio playing).  I've had no nausea but did have bad indigestion on Saturday and it's still not 100% gone now but isn't causing me any problems (actually worse before I eat than after so I'm probably eating more than usual) and Sunday and Monday felt like I'd had one late night too many but was still functioning ok and a couple of early nights seem to have sorted that out. I'm working at home today as it's day 9 and my immune system's probably not too keen on meeting any challenges but I'll be back in the office on Monday. My attitude is that so long as I treat this as a minor glitch then that's all it's going to be and that by the autumn this will be over and done with and I can get on with my life again.  I'm making the most of every day I feel good and looking after myself (my nurse recommended full fat milk and nothing diet or low fat but perhaps smaller portions than usual if I find I'm not so active) and on the days when I feel a bit down I remind myself that it will pass.  So far it's working - in a few weeks time I may feel very differently but I think the drugs seem to affect everyone very differently.  I'd be interested to know if anyone else is working through their treatment and how active you're all managing to keep.  Best of luck to everyone, Chrissi xxx
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Kat, no, not OCD.  I'm still finding my way with this.  The warnings about virtually no immune system between days 10 and 14 are scary - I can't remember the last time I had as much as a cold but when I do they usually hit hard.  My hands have never been washed so frequently as the last few days and when I did go out at the weekend I kept as far away from people as possible in the supermarket (I turned up at opening time Saturday morning) and was tempted to put a scarf around my face...  I'm sure I'll get the hang of this but a bit paranoid at the moment - don't want to risk having to postpone any treatments as I want to get this over and done with asap!   So for now it's lots of handwashing, anti-bacterial gel etc... Chrissi
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: Forion, I know what you mean about walking down the street naked painted green - if a doctor told me that was the only way to avoid side-effects I'd be straight out there!  Reading the posts from people not having a great time does make me realise how lucky I am - I'm sitting here thinking "well at least my hair's still here and it's day 15" or "well, I wasn't sick".  I'm sure there were many people who read that I'd had horrible indigestion who were feeling relieved it hadn't happened to them. You've got to laugh... Oh well, this time next week I'll have had the second dose - that's a whole third of my treatment!.  The hospital says I can have a free pamper day at the local hospice if I want - think I'll ask for it to be booked after my third session as I'll be half way then so can have a little celebration. Chrissi x
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: I put on weight after my lumpectomy (before chemo) simply because I wasn't as active as usual and was still eating the same amount - I took the advice of the Macmillan nurse who said to avoid anythng low fat and really wish I had carried on as normal.  Since starting chemo I've put on another half stone.  I'm told putting on up to 10% of your body weight is normal during chemo - partly because you're probably less active than usual but mainly due to the way your body reacts to the steroids you get with your drugs.   My first two FEC doses saw me eating for England!  I literally found it almost impossible to stop eating - I was so hungry!  This time (third FEC) the consultant halved the steroids and ok, I'm more tired, but my appetite is back to what I'd consider normal again.
Posts.Title: Why am i gaining weight???

Posts.Content: Good morning all, I was supposed to be working at the office today but got there to find that one of my colleagues has a sore throat and swollen glands - I'd asked for everyone to phone me first thing if they were going in with bugs but instead of phoning she'd emailed my work email address over the weekend.  I was not happy - just had to turn around and come home again as I didn't want to risk catching the bug.  Hopefully she kept far enough away from me in the short time I was there.  I was really looking forward to getting out of my isolation today (another colleague had germs last week). Apart from that and a slight touch of hayfever I'm feeling ok.  I noticed at the weekend that my physical strength is down on what it should be but I suppose having taken things easy for a month due to the op that's not surprising. Despite the cold cap my hair (just on my head) seems to be shedding more than usual - my comb's had no hairs at all in it from my first session until yesterday so I'm not sure whether it's just normal hair loss delayed a bit or whether it's on the way out.  Maybe I'll have a surf on ebay for headscarves later. If all goes well with my blood tests on Wednesday I'll have the second chemo on Thursday afternoon.   I've stocked up on gaviscon, mints and ginger - will be prepared this time. Good luck to everyone having a chemo session this week and if it's your first, just try to relax - it will soon be over and you'll have a good excuse to put your feet up and be spoilt over the bank holiday. Together we can get through this! Chrissi x
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: I noticed that Asda do a post-surgery bra although it was very boring it was cheap if you want to save money on everyday undies to buy something much nicer for when you want to feel much more sexy.  Most of the bras available do seem expensive considering they really do look as though they've just had a pocket stitched in.  I was lucky enough to have a very small lump so in the end didn't need to go down this route but I did wonder if whether my sewing skills were up to adapting a standard bra.
Posts.Title: bras help

Posts.Content: I've been taking tamoxifen since last July and get cramps in my back and legs at night.  Sometimes I can go several weeks with out any problems, sometimes it's everytime I move in the night.  The next day my legs feel like I've climbed a mountain and straightening up if my back's been cramped takes a good hour or so!  I'll be interested to know if quinine works as self-medicating with a nightly G&T would be no problem at all!   I mentioned the cramps to the oncologist at my Feb check-up (along with not being able to lose weight, sleep etc) and just got a "I've not heard of that before" - hmmm.  To be honest she wasn't actually much help - just recommended more exercise to lose weight which would help with the sleep, flushes etc.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and muscle cramps

Posts.Content: I'm experiencing the same - the cramps come every night for a week or so then nothing for a few weeks, then back to cramps again.  I've got my second quarterly checkup on the 1st so will be asking about that.  I'm building up a list of things to ask about, most of which I suspect are related to tamoxifen.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and muscle cramps
